teaching_point: An object at rest will remain at rest unless a force causes it to move.
visual_explanation: A toy car sits still on a smooth, wooden floor. A hand gently pushes it, and it rolls forward a short distance. The background is a brightly lit playroom.

questions.retrieval_prompt: just before the hand touches the car
questions.question: Is the toy car stationary before it is pushed by the hand?
questions.statement: The toy car is not moving before being pushed
questions.antonym: The toy car is already moving before it is pushed

questions.retrieval_prompt: just after the hand releases the car
questions.question: Does the toy car move forward after being pushed by the hand?
questions.statement: The toy car moves forward once the hand applies a force
questions.antonym: The toy car remains stationary even after being pushed

teaching_point: An object in motion will continue moving at the same speed and in the same direction unless a force changes it.
visual_explanation: A rolling ball continues to travel in a straight line across a grassy field. The background is a sunny field with a distant fence.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the ball is mid-way across the field
questions.question: Is the ball moving in a straight line across the field?
questions.statement: The ball's path is straight, showing no change in direction
questions.antonym: The ball's path curves or changes direction

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the ball still rolling and not stopped by any obstacle?
questions.statement: The ball is still in motion and not stopped
questions.antonym: The ball is stopped or blocked by an obstacle

teaching_point: The more mass an object has, the harder it is to change its motion.
visual_explanation: A small, lightweight ball rolls easily when pushed, while on pushing a large, heavy bowling ball it starts moving later.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both balls have just been pushed
questions.question: Does the lightweight ball begin moving before the heavy bowling ball?
questions.statement: The lightweight ball is already rolling while the heavy ball has not yet started moving
questions.antonym: Both balls start moving at the same time

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the heavy bowling ball still closer to its starting position than the lightweight ball?
questions.statement: The heavy bowling ball has traveled a shorter distance than the lightweight ball after being pushed
questions.antonym: The heavy bowling ball has moved as far or farther than the lightweight ball

teaching_point: When a force is applied, an object accelerates in the direction of that force.
visual_explanation: A person pushes a shopping cart; the cart begins to move down a smooth aisle. The background shows a supermarket aisle.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the person has just released the cart - that is pushed the cart
questions.question: Is the shopping cart moving forward in the same direction as the push?
questions.statement: The cart is moving forward along the aisle, matching the direction of the push
questions.antonym: The cart is stationary or moving in a different direction

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the cart is in motion without the person touching it
questions.question: Is the cart moving without anyone touching it after being pushed?
questions.statement: The cart continues to move on its own after the push, showing inertia
questions.antonym: The cart stops immediately once the person lets go

teaching_point: A heavier object requires a greater force to produce the same acceleration.
visual_explanation: Two people push identical-looking sleds on snow: one is empty, and it glides forward quickly. The other is filled with supplies and moves much more slowly despite equal pushing force. The background is a snowy field.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both sleds are being pushed forward together
questions.question: Is the empty sled moving ahead of the loaded sled, even though both are being pushed with equal force?
questions.statement: The empty sled is farther ahead than the loaded sled under equal pushing force
questions.antonym: Both sleds are side by side or the loaded sled is ahead

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both pushers have just finished pushing
questions.question: Does the loaded sled appear to move more slowly than the empty sled after being pushed?
questions.statement: The loaded sled lags behind, showing less acceleration
questions.antonym: The loaded sled moves as fast as or faster than the empty sled

teaching_point: A larger force results in a larger change in motion.
visual_explanation: A student gently pushes a cart, and it moves a short distance. Then, the student gives it a strong push, and it accelerates rapidly down the same hallway. The setting is a school corridor with smooth flooring.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the cart is moving after the strong push
questions.question: Is the cart moving noticeably faster after the strong push compared to after the gentle push?
questions.statement: The cart is seen moving much faster after the strong push
questions.antonym: The cart moves at the same speed after both pushes

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Does the cart travel a much greater distance after the strong push than after the gentle push?
questions.statement: The cart has covered a much longer distance after the strong push
questions.antonym: The cart has traveled about the same distance after both pushes

teaching_point: The same force causes different accelerations depending on the object's mass.
visual_explanation: A robot arm applies equal force to two blocks on a conveyor belt: one block is small and speeds up quickly, the other is large and moves slowly. The background is a lab setting.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both blocks have just started moving after being pushed
questions.question: Is the smaller block ahead of the larger block on the conveyor belt?
questions.statement: The smaller block has moved farther than the larger block after receiving the same force
questions.antonym: Both blocks are at the same position

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the robot arm is in contact with both blocks
questions.question: Do both blocks have visibly different speeds as they move away from the robot arm?
questions.statement: The small block moves away faster than the large block under equal force
questions.antonym: Both blocks move at the same speed

teaching_point: When one object exerts a force on another, the other exerts an equal and opposite force in return.
visual_explanation: A person vigorously pushes against a large wall. The wall exerts an equal and opposite force on the person, preventing them from moving forward. The background is a simple, empty hallway.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the person is pushing against the wall with arms extended
questions.question: Is the person unable to move forward while pushing against the wall?
questions.statement: The person remains stationary despite pushing hard on the wall
questions.antonym: The person moves forward through the wall

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the person's hands are visibly pressing against the wall
questions.question: Is the wall not moving despite the person pushing hard against it?
questions.statement: The wall stays in place as the person pushes
questions.antonym: The wall moves backward

teaching_point: The forces are always equal in magnitude but act in opposite directions.
visual_explanation: A rocket expels hot gas downwards with tremendous force. Simultaneously, the rocket moves upwards with an equal and opposite force. The background is a desert landscape with a rocket launch site.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the rocket has just lifted off the ground
questions.question: Is the rocket moving upward while hot gas is expelled downward?
questions.statement: The rocket is rising as a visible stream of hot gas moves downward.
questions.antonym: The rocket stays still while gas is expelled, or the rocket moves without gas expelled.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both the rocket and the expelled gas are clearly visible
questions.question: Are the directions of the rocket’s motion and the expelled gas opposite to each other?
questions.statement: The rocket moves upward while the expelled gas is directed downward, showing opposite directions.
questions.antonym: The rocket and the gas move in the same direction, or only one is moving.

teaching_point: The action and reaction forces always act on different objects.
visual_explanation: A swimmer pushes against water with their hands. The water pushes back on the swimmer with equal force, propelling them forward. The background is a swimming pool.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the swimmer's hands are pressing against the water
questions.question: Are the swimmer’s hands pushing backward against the water while the swimmer’s body moves forward?
questions.statement: The swimmer’s hands are pressing back on the water as the swimmer’s body moves in the opposite direction
questions.antonym: The swimmer’s body and hands both move in the same direction, or there is no visible backward push

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the swimmer is moving forward after pushing the water
questions.question: Is the water behind the swimmer disturbed or splashing where the hands pushed?
questions.statement: There is visible disturbance or splash in the water behind the swimmer’s hands, indicating the water received a force
questions.antonym: The water behind the swimmer is calm with no disturbance

teaching_point: Static Equilibrium
visual_explanation: A small wooden block sits perfectly still on a smooth, flat surface. A gentle breeze rustles nearby leaves. The background shows a sunlit garden.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the wooden block stationary on the surface?
questions.statement: The wooden block is not moving and remains in place on the surface
questions.antonym: The block is sliding or has moved from its original place

teaching_point: Dynamic Equilibrium
visual_explanation: A toy car moves continuously down a straight track, never slowing down or changing direction. The background is a brightly colored playroom.

questions.retrieval_prompt: any time while the car is moving along the track
questions.question: Is the toy car moving in a straight line without turning?
questions.statement: The car's wheels stay aligned with the track and it does not veer left or right
questions.antonym: The car is turning or moving off the straight track

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the toy car's speed unchanged compared to earlier in the video?
questions.statement: The car is still moving at the same speed as before, with no signs of slowing down or speeding up
questions.antonym: The car has slowed down or stopped

teaching_point: If the net force on an object is zero, it stays at rest or keeps moving at constant speed.
visual_explanation: A seesaw balances perfectly with a child on one side and a toy on the other. The background shows a park with families playing.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the seesaw perfectly horizontal, showing that it is balanced?
questions.statement: The seesaw is level, indicating no net force acting to tip it.
questions.antonym: The seesaw is tilted to one side.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Are both the child and the toy stationary on the seesaw?
questions.statement: Neither the child nor the toy is moving, showing the system is at rest.
questions.antonym: The child or the toy is moving or sliding.

teaching_point: Friction opposes motion when two surfaces rub against each other.
visual_explanation: A child pushes a toy car across a carpeted floor. As soon as the child stops pushing, the car quickly slows down and stops. Close-up shows the tiny fibers of the carpet rubbing against the wheels.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Has the toy car come to a stop after being pushed?
questions.statement: The car is stationary at the end of the scene
questions.antonym: The car is still moving

questions.retrieval_prompt: during the close-up on the wheels and carpet fibers
questions.question: Can you see the carpet fibers in contact with the toy car's wheels?
questions.statement: The close-up reveals the carpet fibers touching the wheels
questions.antonym: There is no visible contact between the fibers and the wheels

teaching_point: The normal force pushes up from a surface to support an object resting on it.
visual_explanation: A book lies flat on a table. A subtle arrow points upward from the table surface, countering the downward arrow of the book’s weight. The background shows a quiet study room with shelves of books.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is there an upward arrow from the table indicating a normal force supporting the book?
questions.statement: A clear upward arrow extends from the table into the book, indicating the normal force.
questions.antonym: No upward arrow is present from the table.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the book lying flat and supported on the table, without sinking through it?
questions.statement: The book rests level on the table’s surface, showing it is supported.
questions.antonym: The book is partly or fully below the table surface, as if unsupported.

teaching_point: Tension is the pulling force carried by strings or ropes.
visual_explanation: A person pulls a bucket up from a well using a rope. The rope stretches slightly as the bucket rises. The background includes a stone well, grassy field, and trees swaying in the breeze.

questions.retrieval_prompt: while the bucket is being lifted above the well
questions.question: Is the rope stretched as the bucket is being pulled up?
questions.statement: The rope is visibly stretched and taut while lifting the bucket
questions.antonym: The rope appears slack and unstretched

questions.retrieval_prompt: while the person is pulling on the rope
questions.question: Is the person pulling on the rope to lift the bucket?
questions.statement: The person is holding and pulling the rope upwards, causing the bucket to rise
questions.antonym: The person is not touching or pulling the rope

teaching_point: An applied force causes an object to accelerate if it’s unbalanced.
visual_explanation: A person pushes a heavy box across a smooth floor. The box slowly starts moving. Arrows show the direction of the push and the resulting movement. The setting is an empty room with stacked furniture.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the box has just started to move
questions.question: Is the box moving in the same direction as the push?
questions.statement: The box is moving in the direction indicated by the push arrow
questions.antonym: The box remains stationary or moves in a different direction

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the box is moving and both arrows are visible
questions.question: Are the arrows showing the applied force and the movement of the box pointing in the same direction?
questions.statement: Both arrows point in the same direction, indicating the force and movement align
questions.antonym: The arrows point in different directions

teaching_point: A spring exerts a restoring force when stretched or compressed.
visual_explanation: A hand stretches a coiled spring attached to a wall. Once released, the spring snaps back to its original shape. Arrows illustrate the tension and restoring force. The scene is a clean science lab bench with equipment.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the hand is stretching the spring and arrows are shown
questions.question: Are there arrows pointing from the spring toward its original (unstretched) length, indicating a restoring force?
questions.statement: Arrows on the image point toward the spring's original position, showing the direction of the restoring force.
questions.antonym: No arrows are present or they point away from the original position

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Has the spring returned to its original, un-stretched shape after being released?
questions.statement: The spring is visibly back to its original length and shape.
questions.antonym: The spring remains stretched or deformed

teaching_point: Displacement describes the change in position of an object.
visual_explanation: A toy car starts at point A, moves in a straight line to point B, then returns to point A following a wide parabolic arc. At the end of the motion, the straight-line path from point A to point B is softly highlighted on the table surface. The background is a clean wooden table in a brightly lit room.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the toy car back at its original starting point (point A)?
questions.statement: The toy car is located at point A in the final scene
questions.antonym: The toy car is located elsewhere, not at point A

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the straight-line path between point A and point B highlighted on the table?
questions.statement: A softly highlighted straight line connects point A and point B
questions.antonym: No straight-line path is highlighted between point A and point B

teaching_point: Velocity describes how quickly and in what direction an object is changing its position.
visual_explanation: A skateboarder moves quickly along a straight path, then turns a corner and continues at a different speed. The background shows a skate park with ramps and curves.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the skateboarder is just starting to turn the corner
questions.question: Is the skateboarder's direction of motion changing as they turn the corner?
questions.statement: The skateboarder is no longer moving straight and is changing direction around the corner
questions.antonym: The skateboarder continues moving in a straight line

questions.retrieval_prompt: after the skateboarder has completed the turn
questions.question: Is the skateboarder's speed different after turning the corner compared to before?
questions.statement: The skateboarder's speed changes after the turn, indicating a change in velocity
questions.antonym: The skateboarder's speed remains the same before and after the turn

teaching_point: Acceleration describes how quickly and in what direction an object’s velocity is changing.
visual_explanation: A bicycle speeds up as the rider pushes down on the pedal, and then slows down as the rider applies the brakes. The background shows a cyclist on a road.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the rider is pushing down on the pedal
questions.question: Is the bicycle moving faster than before the rider pushed the pedal?
questions.statement: The bicycle is visually farther along the road compared to previous frames, indicating increased speed
questions.antonym: The bicycle's position does not change noticeably or it moves at the same speed

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the rider is applying the brakes
questions.question: Does the bicycle appear to be slowing down as the rider applies the brakes?
questions.statement: The rider's posture and wheel motion indicate deceleration, such as leaning back.
questions.antonym: The bicycle continues moving at the same speed or keeps accelerating

teaching_point: Motion in 1D occurs along a single straight line
visual_explanation: A toy train moves back and forth along a straight track. The background shows a wall-mounted number line tracking its position.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the train is moving on the track
questions.question: Is the train confined to moving along a single straight track?
questions.statement: The train only moves back and forth along a straight line
questions.antonym: The train follows a curved or branching path

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the train is at a new position on the number line
questions.question: Does the train's position correspond to a single value on the number line in the background?
questions.statement: Each position of the train aligns with one value on the number line
questions.antonym: The train's position does not match any number on the number line or matches multiple values

teaching_point: In 2D motion, position is described using two coordinates, such as x and y.
visual_explanation: A drone flies diagonally over a grid marked on the ground, with its changing x and y positions traced as a glowing path. The scene is set in a wide-open park.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the drone is mid-flight over the grid
questions.question: Is the drone positioned at a point where both its x and y coordinates can be identified on the ground grid?
questions.statement: The drone’s location matches a unique intersection of x and y lines on the grid
questions.antonym: The drone’s position cannot be described using both x and y coordinates

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Does the glowing path traced by the drone show changes in both x and y directions?
questions.statement: The path is diagonal, indicating movement across both x and y axes
questions.antonym: The path is along only one axis (x or y), not both

teaching_point: An object launched upwards follows a curved path due to gravity.
visual_explanation: A ball is thrown from a hilltop and follows a smooth, curved path before landing. The background shows a grassy hill with a clear sky.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the ball is mid-air above the hilltop
questions.question: Is the ball following a curved path as it moves through the air?
questions.statement: The ball's trajectory is visibly curved rather than straight
questions.antonym: The ball moves along a straight line

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Has the ball landed below its starting point on the hilltop?
questions.statement: The ball is resting on the ground lower than the hilltop launch point
questions.antonym: The ball remains at or above the hilltop

teaching_point: The initial launch direction affects the object's range.
visual_explanation: Two identical balls are launched from the same height—one vertically upward and the other at an angle. Both follow curved paths and land at different distances on a flat field. The background is a wide open grassy area.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Do the two balls land at different distances from their starting point?
questions.statement: The two balls are on the ground at visibly different distances from where they started.
questions.antonym: Both balls land at the same spot.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both balls are mid-air along their paths
questions.question: Are the two balls following visibly different curved trajectories?
questions.statement: Each ball traces a distinct path: one goes nearly straight up and down, while the other follows a longer, angled arc.
questions.antonym: Both balls move along identical paths.

teaching_point: Gravity constantly pulls the object downwards, causing a downward acceleration.
visual_explanation: A person tosses a ball straight up while standing on a beach. The ball slows as it rises, pauses momentarily at its peak, then accelerates downward back into the person’s hand. The background shows sand and ocean waves.

questions.retrieval_prompt: at the highest point of the ball's trajectory (when the ball pauses at its peak)
questions.question: Is the ball momentarily at rest at the top of its path, before starting to fall down?
questions.statement: The ball is not moving upward or downward at the peak; it is momentarily stationary.
questions.antonym: The ball is still moving upward or is already falling quickly at the peak.

questions.retrieval_prompt: just after the ball begins to fall back down (when it has started descending)
questions.question: Does the ball move downward after reaching its highest point?
questions.statement: The ball changes direction and moves downward, showing gravity's effect.
questions.antonym: The ball remains at the same height or continues moving upward.

teaching_point: Observers in different frames of reference perceive motion differently
visual_explanation: A person holds a ball while riding a skateboard. The skateboard moves forward. Another person stands still and watches. The ball looks still to the rider but looks like it's moving to the observer.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the skateboard is moving forward with the person holding the ball
questions.question: From the perspective of the stationary observer, does the ball appear to be moving forward?
questions.statement: The stationary observer sees the ball and the rider both moving forward
questions.antonym: The ball appears stationary to the stationary observer

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the skateboard is moving and the rider is holding the ball
questions.question: Does the ball appear still relative to the person riding the skateboard?
questions.statement: The ball is not moving relative to the rider holding it
questions.antonym: The ball appears to move relative to the rider

teaching_point: Relative motion in same direction
visual_explanation: Two cars drive side by side in the same direction at slightly different speeds. The camera follows the slower car as the other car slowly pulls ahead.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the faster car is visibly ahead of the slower car
questions.question: Is the faster car ahead of the slower car while both are moving in the same direction?
questions.statement: The faster car is visibly ahead of the slower car, both traveling in the same direction
questions.antonym: Both cars are side by side

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the slower car still visible in the frame after the faster car has pulled ahead?
questions.statement: The slower car remains in view as the camera follows it, while the faster car is further ahead
questions.antonym: The slower car is no longer visible

teaching_point: Relative motion in different direction
visual_explanation: Two trains move on parallel tracks—one from left to right, the other from right to left. The camera stays still between the tracks, showing the trains moving past each other in opposite directions.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both trains are visible near each other
questions.question: Are the two trains moving past each other in opposite directions?
questions.statement: One train moves left to right and the other right to left in the same frame
questions.antonym: Both trains move in the same direction or only one train is moving

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both trains are side by side in the frame
questions.question: Does the camera remain stationary between the trains as they move?
questions.statement: Both trains are seen moving in opposite directions while the camera's viewpoint remains fixed
questions.antonym: The camera moves along with one of the trains or both trains are stationary

teaching_point: Objects moving at the same speed and direction appear stationary relative to each other.
visual_explanation: Two toy cars move side by side at the same speed on a flat surface. The camera moves along with them, showing the cars staying aligned and appearing still relative to each other as the background shifts.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both cars are in view and the background is visible
questions.question: Do the two toy cars appear side by side and aligned with each other?
questions.statement: Both cars remain next to each other, appearing stationary relative to each other
questions.antonym: The cars are not aligned or one is ahead of the other

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both cars and the background are visible
questions.question: Does the background appear blurred or shifted while the cars remain stationary relative to each other?
questions.statement: The background shows motion (blur or shift) while the cars appear still relative to each other
questions.antonym: The background and cars both appear stationary

teaching_point: An object moving in a circle is constantly changing direction.
visual_explanation: Toy car moves in a circle, direction constantly changes, simplified race track.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the car is on a curved section of the track
questions.question: Is the car pointed tangentially to the circular track rather than straight ahead?
questions.statement: The car is oriented tangentially to the circle, showing its direction is changing
questions.antonym: The car remains pointed in the same direction as before

questions.retrieval_prompt: at two different points on the track (compare orientation)
questions.question: Does the car's direction differ at different positions along the circular track?
questions.statement: At various positions, the car points in different directions along the path
questions.antonym: The car points in the same direction at all positions

teaching_point: A centripetal force is required to keep an object moving in a circle
visual_explanation: A person holds a string with a ball tied to the end and spins it in a circle. The camera shows the ball moving around while the string stays tight, clearly pulling the ball toward the center.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the ball is mid-way in the circle
questions.question: Is the string pulled tight, pointing from the ball toward the person's hand?
questions.statement: The string is taut and directs from the ball to the center, showing the centripetal force.
questions.antonym: The string is slack or not pointing toward the center.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the ball is mid-way in the circle
questions.question: Is the ball's path curved around the person rather than moving straight away?
questions.statement: The ball is moving along a curved path around the person.
questions.antonym: The ball is moving in a straight line away from the circle.

teaching_point: The direction of velocity is always tangent to the circular path
visual_explanation: An overhead view of a toy car driving in a circular path. At several points along the circle, arrows show the car’s velocity pointing straight along the tangent, not toward the center.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the velocity arrows are shown at several points along the path
questions.question: Do the velocity arrows at each point, tangent to the circle rather than toward the center?
questions.statement: Each velocity arrow is tangent to the circular path, not pointing inward
questions.antonym: The velocity arrows point toward the center of the circle

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the toy car is at any point along the circle with the velocity arrow shown
questions.question: Is the direction of the velocity arrow perpendicular to the radius at that point?
questions.statement: The velocity arrow forms a right angle with the radius from the center to the car
questions.antonym: The velocity arrow is parallel to the radius, not perpendicular

teaching_point: If the centripetal force is removed, the object moves in a straight line
visual_explanation: A ball tied to a string is being swung in a circle. Suddenly, the string breaks. The camera follows the ball as it moves off in a straight line tangent to the circle.

questions.retrieval_prompt: immediately after the string breaks
questions.question: Does the ball move in a straight line tangent to the circle after the string breaks?
questions.statement: The ball travels in a straight path tangent to the circle's edge where the string broke
questions.antonym: The ball continues moving in a curved or circular path

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the ball no longer attached to the string at the end of the scene?
questions.statement: The ball is separated from the string
questions.antonym: The ball is still tied to the string

teaching_point: Moving an object requires applying a force over a distance.
visual_explanation: A person pushes a box across a floor. The box moves a short distance. The background is a simple warehouse.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Has the box changed position from its starting point?
questions.statement: The box is visibly farther from its original location
questions.antonym: The box remains in its original position

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the person is pushing the box
questions.question: Is the person's hands in contact with the box, applying force?
questions.statement: The person's hands are pushing against the box
questions.antonym: The person is not touching the box

teaching_point: The amount of work done depends on both the strength of the force and how far the object moves with that force.
visual_explanation: A hand pushes a large boulder and a small rock. The boulder moves a short distance, while the rock moves a long distance. The background is a rocky hillside.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Has the small rock moved a greater distance from its starting point than the large boulder?
questions.statement: The small rock is much farther from its original position than the large boulder
questions.antonym: Both objects have moved the same distance

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both the small rock and boulder are being pushed by the hand
questions.question: Is the hand applying force to both the large boulder and the small rock at the same time?
questions.statement: The hand is visibly pushing both objects simultaneously
questions.antonym: The hand is only pushing one object or none

teaching_point: If a force acts in the same direction as an object’s movement, it performs positive work.
visual_explanation: A child pulls a wagon down a gentle slope. The wagon moves steadily. The background shows a park path.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the child is pulling the wagon
questions.question: Is the child pulling the wagon in the same direction that the wagon is moving?
questions.statement: The child is pulling the wagon and both are moving down the slope in the same direction
questions.antonym: The child pulls in a different direction than the wagon moves

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the wagon positioned farther down the slope than where it started?
questions.statement: The wagon has moved down the slope, away from its starting point
questions.antonym: The wagon remains at its original position

teaching_point: If a force acts against the direction of an object’s movement, it performs negative work.
visual_explanation: A hand pushes against a heavy box trying to move it across the floor. The box does not move. The background is a clean workshop.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the hand is pushing on the box
questions.question: Is the box stationary while the hand is pushing on it?
questions.statement: The box does not move despite the hand pushing against it
questions.antonym: The box is moving across the floor

teaching_point: When an object moves, it has energy related to its motion – this is kinetic energy.
visual_explanation: A child runs across the field, picking up speed as they sprint.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the child is mid-sprint
questions.question: Is the child visibly off the ground, showing forward motion?
questions.statement: The child is airborne with a forward-leaning posture, indicating active movement and kinetic energy
questions.antonym: The child is standing still or not showing any forward motion

questions.antonym: The waves are irregular or not forming consistent circles

teaching_point: An incoherent source produces waves that are different shapes and travel in different directions.
visual_explanation: Multiple objects – a bell, a speaker, and a drum – vibrate simultaneously in a small room. Waves radiate outwards from each object, appearing as chaotic, overlapping circles and irregular patterns spreading throughout the space. The background shows a basic office environment.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when all three objects are vibrating
questions.question: Do the waves from the bell, speaker, and drum have different shapes and directions?
questions.statement: The waves emanating from each object are visibly distinct in form and spread in various directions
questions.antonym: All waves have the same shape and travel in the same direction

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the room is filled with overlapping waves
questions.question: Are the wave patterns in the room irregular and overlapping, rather than forming a clear, repeating pattern?
questions.statement: The room shows chaotic, intersecting wavefronts without a regular or repeating structure
questions.antonym: The waves form a regular, repeating pattern

teaching_point: Heat engines convert thermal energy into mechanical work.
visual_explanation: A steam locomotive's wheels start turning as steam rises from the engine.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when steam is visibly rising from the engine and the wheels are turning
questions.question: Are the locomotive's wheels turning while steam rises from the engine?
questions.statement: The locomotive's wheels are rotating as steam escapes the engine
questions.antonym: The wheels remain still while steam rises

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the locomotive moving forward as a result of the turning wheels?
questions.statement: The locomotive has changed position, showing it moved forward due to mechanical work
questions.antonym: The locomotive remains stationary even though steam is produced

teaching_point: The efficiency of a heat engine is the ratio of work output to heat input.
visual_explanation: Two identical steam locomotives, one moving faster than the other, while both emit the same amount of steam.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when both locomotives are side by side and emitting steam
questions.question: Is one locomotive moving faster than the other even though both emit the same amount of steam?
questions.statement: One locomotive is faster compared to the other, while both have the same amount of steam emitted.
questions.antonym: Both locomotives move at the same speed

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the steam clouds from both locomotives are visible
questions.question: Do both locomotives emit equal amounts of steam despite their different speeds?
questions.statement: Both locomotives have similar-sized steam clouds emerging from their stacks.
questions.antonym: One locomotive emits more steam than the other

teaching_point: Refrigerators move thermal energy from a cool environment to a warmer one.
visual_explanation: Ice cubes inside a transparent fridge begin to melt while the back of the fridge releases warm air.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Are the ice cubes partially melted inside the fridge?
questions.statement: The ice cubes appear smaller or partially liquid inside the fridge
questions.antonym: The ice cubes are still completely solid

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is there visible warm air (or heat waves) at the back of the fridge?
questions.statement: The back of the fridge shows warm air or heat waves being released
questions.antonym: No sign of warm air or heat waves at the back

teaching_point: Entropy is a measure of the disorder or randomness in a system.
visual_explanation: Show a box of neatly arranged red and blue balls. Then shake the box — the balls randomly mix and spread out, representing increased disorder.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Are the red and blue balls randomly mixed and spread out in the box?
questions.statement: The balls are scattered throughout the box without any order
questions.antonym: The balls are still neatly arranged by color

questions.retrieval_prompt: at the start, before shaking the box
questions.question: Are the red and blue balls neatly arranged in an orderly pattern?
questions.statement: The balls are sorted by color and arranged neatly
questions.antonym: The balls are already mixed and disordered

teaching_point: In natural processes, entropy tends to increase, leading to more disordered states over time.
visual_explanation: Show an ice cube melting into water. The initially ordered structure of the ice transitions into disordered liquid molecules, represented by free-moving particles.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Has the ice cube completely melted into liquid water?
questions.statement: There is no visible ice left; only liquid water is present
questions.antonym: The ice cube is still solid or partially solid

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Are the particles in the liquid water more randomly arranged than in the original ice cube?
questions.statement: Particles are shown moving freely and disordered in the liquid water
questions.antonym: Particles remain fixed in a regular, ordered structure

teaching_point: Entropy increases when energy becomes more spread out and less available to do useful work.
visual_explanation: Show hot gas particles in one half of a box. After removing a partition, the gas spreads evenly throughout, symbolizing energy spreading out and becoming less usable.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Are the gas particles spread evenly throughout the entire box?
questions.statement: The gas particles are distributed evenly in both halves of the box
questions.antonym: The gas particles are still confined to one side

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the partition that originally separated the box now completely removed?
questions.statement: The partition is absent, allowing gas particles to fill the whole box
questions.antonym: The partition is still in place, restricting the gas to one side

teaching_point: Converging lenses (convex) focus parallel rays of light to a single point known as the focal point.
visual_explanation: Show parallel rays of sunlight entering a clear convex lens. Slowly trace each ray bending inward and meeting at a single bright point on the opposite side, labeled 'F'. Use a zoom-in to emphasize the convergence and lens shape.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the rays have just passed through the lens and meet at point 'F'
questions.question: Do all the parallel rays converge to a single point on the far side of the lens?
questions.statement: All rays meet at a single bright point labeled 'F' after passing through the lens
questions.antonym: The rays remain parallel or do not meet at a single point

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the rays are entering the lens
questions.question: Are the incoming rays parallel to each other before passing through the lens?
questions.statement: All rays approach the lens in parallel lines
questions.antonym: The rays are not parallel as they approach the lens

teaching_point: Diverging lenses (concave) spread out parallel rays of light away from a single point.
visual_explanation: Show parallel light rays entering a concave lens. As they pass through, animate each ray bending outward. Extend dotted lines backward behind the lens to intersect at a point labeled 'F'.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Do the rays emerging from the concave lens spread outward after passing through the lens?
questions.statement: The rays diverge as they exit the lens
questions.antonym: The rays continue parallel without spreading

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Do the backward extensions of the diverging rays meet at a single point labeled 'F' behind the lens?
questions.statement: The dotted backward extensions intersect at point 'F'
questions.antonym: The backward extensions do not meet at a single point

teaching_point: The image formed by a concave lens is always virtual, upright, and smaller than the object, no matter where the object is placed.
visual_explanation: Place an object (e.g., a candle) in front of a concave lens. Show the principal rays: one parallel (diverges as if from focal point), one toward the center (passes straight). Mark the rays' extensions meeting behind the object to form a small upright virtual image.

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the image of the object formed on the same side of the lens as the object (virtual image)?
questions.statement: The image is shown behind the lens on the same side as the object, indicated by dashed ray extensions meeting there.
questions.antonym: The image is formed on the opposite side of the lens (real image)

questions.retrieval_prompt: Last Frame
questions.question: Is the image upright and smaller than the object?
questions.statement: The image is upright (same orientation as the object) and clearly smaller in height than the object.
questions.antonym: The image is inverted or the same size/larger than the object

teaching_point: Resonance occurs when a system is driven by an external force at its natural frequency, leading to large amplitude oscillations.
visual_explanation: Show a child sitting on a swing. Initially, the pushes are irregular, and the swing barely moves. Then, demonstrate the child being pushed at regular intervals matching the swing’s natural back-and-forth motion. With each well-timed push, the swing’s amplitude increases noticeably. Clearly highlight that the energy transfer is most efficient when the pushing frequency matches the swing’s natural frequency.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the pushes are timed with the swing’s natural motion and the swing reaches its highest point
questions.question: Is the swing reaching a much higher amplitude when the pushes are given at regular intervals matching its natural frequency?
questions.statement: The swing rises to a much higher angle during resonance
questions.antonym: The swing barely moves and does not reach a high amplitude

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the pushes are irregular and the swing is at its maximum displacement
questions.question: Does the swing remain at a low amplitude when the pushes are irregular?
questions.statement: The swing only moves slightly and does not reach a high angle
questions.antonym: The swing reaches a high amplitude even with irregular pushes

teaching_point: Different systems have different natural frequencies; resonance occurs only when the driving frequency matches the system’s natural frequency.
visual_explanation: Show three identical glass goblets placed side by side, each labeled with a different natural frequency (f₁, f₂, f₃). A nearby speaker emits a sound that gradually sweeps across frequencies. When the sound matches f₂, the middle goblet begins to visibly vibrate, possibly showing cracking or distortion. The other goblets remain unaffected. Use animated wave patterns to visually represent the matching frequencies.

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the middle goblet is visibly vibrating
questions.question: Is the middle goblet (f₂) showing signs of vibration or distortion while the other two goblets (f₁ and f₃) remain still?
questions.statement: Only the middle goblet vibrates or shows distortion, while the others remain unaffected
questions.antonym: All goblets are still, or more than one goblet is vibrating

questions.retrieval_prompt: when the animated wave pattern matches the frequency label f₂
questions.question: Is the emitted sound's frequency (as shown by the animated wave) matching the natural frequency label (f₂) of the vibrating goblet?
questions.statement: The animated wave pattern from the speaker aligns with the f₂ label on the vibrating goblet
questions.antonym: The wave pattern does not match the f₂ label, or the vibrating goblet's label differs from the wave frequency
